conclusion: Acceleration is the rate of change of velocity with respect to time.
On a v-t graph, acceleration is represented by the slope of the curve.
The steepness of the slope indicates the magnitude of acceleration.
Object A follows the upper curve which appears to be parabolic.
At t = 0, the curve for Object A starts with zero velocity and a positive slope.

premise: Object A follows the upper curve which appears to be parabolic.
conclusion: As time progresses, the slope for Object A increases initially.

premise: Object A follows the upper curve which appears to be parabolic.
conclusion: After reaching a point of inflection, the slope for Object A starts decreasing.

premise: Object A follows the upper curve which appears to be parabolic.
conclusion: Near t₁, the slope for Object A becomes zero at the peak.
Object B follows the lower curve which also appears to be parabolic but with a smaller amplitude.
At t = 0, the curve for Object B starts with zero velocity and a positive slope.

premise: Object B follows the lower curve which also appears to be parabolic.
conclusion: The slope for Object B appears to increase initially.

premise: Object B follows the lower curve which also appears to be parabolic.
conclusion: After some point, the slope for Object B starts decreasing.

conclusion: Both objects' accelerations first increase and then decrease.
